doc.repnme: Budgeting implications for ATI legislation : the Mexican case
doc.abstracts: This paper analyzes the budgeting implications of implementation of access to information (ATI) legislation in Mexico. Any policy process is characterized by adoption and implementation phases. In the case of ATI policies, the adoption phase generally ends with the approval of an ATI law, and thus budgeting is passed on entirely to the implementation phase. This paper address the components (that is, budgetary elements) that legislators and public officials should bear in mind, both when adopting and implementing an ATI law, but is not a study of projected costs. Using the Mexican case, it focuses on the issues that must be taken into account for planning budgetary needs before and after passing legislation.
doc.docna: Budgeting implications for ATI legislation : the Mexican case
doc.display_title: Budgeting implications for ATI legislation : the Mexican case
